name: Swamp Wallaby
description: It has a typical 'kangaroo-like' appearance. The front five-toed limbs are short and weak, mainly used for handling food. The hind legs are strong, with a vestigial thumb and partially fused toes, the fourth being the longest and strongest—an adaptation for long, high leaps when fleeing danger. The swamp wallaby has dark brown fur, darker limbs and tail, a lighter yellowish belly, and often a yellow stripe on its cheeks.
food_note: Grass, herbs, shrubs, tree seedlings, and fungi
proportions: Body length 67–84 cm; tail length 64–86 cm; average height 70 cm; weight 10.5–20 kg
reproduction: Females are pregnant for 33–38 days and bear 1 young, carried in the pouch for 8–9 months
attractions: Unlike other kangaroos, it commonly seeks cooling in water. It has a varied diet and can safely eat plants toxic to humans. Females can become pregnant again just eight days before giving birth to the previous offspring.
